utterances: This race was one of the longest and most contentious in modern U.S.
history.
Both candidates worked tirelessly to convince voters they were the best equipped to lead the country into a new and uniquely challenging era.
From the beginning, Senator Obama focused his message on hope and change.
You have shown what history teaches us.
That at defining moments like this one, the change we need doesn't come from Washington; change comes to Washington.
(Soundbite of applause)
Senator McCain declared himself a maverick within his Republican Party and reminded voters that he spent years as a prisoner of war in Vietnam.
Then, I found myself falling toward the middle of a small lake in the city of Hanoi, with two broken arms, a broken leg, and an angry crowd waiting to greet me.
In the end, the collapsing economy, combined with Senator Obama's core message of change, resonated with the majority of the electorate.
A record number of Americans came out to vote on Election Day, with an estimated 136.6 million people casting ballots.
Few question that race and gender affected the presidential contest, including the marked increase in the black vote, with an African-American on the ballot for the first time.
This election also marked only the second time in American history that a woman, Republican vice presidential nominee Sarah Palin, was on the ballot for a major party.
I was just your average hockey mom and signed up for the PTA.

I love those hockey moms.
You know, they say the difference between a hockey mom and a pit bull?
Lipstick.
(Soundbite of laughter and applause)
Last night was the culmination of a formal contest that began 21 months ago.
I chose to run for president at this moment in history because I believe deeply that we cannot solve the challenges of our time unless we solve them together.
Obama was considered an underdog at the beginning of his campaign.
He shocked even his own party when he won the Iowa caucuses.

In lines that stretched around schools and churches, in small towns and in big cities, you came together as Democrats, Republicans, and Independents to stand up and say that we are one nation, we are one people, and our time for change has come.
(Soundbite of cheering)

One thing that was very clear about him was that in his way, he was a real foodie.
I mean, he didn't write a letter that he didn't talk about what he'd been eating.
You know, dear mom and dad, guess what I had for breakfast?
And they say that he was a foodie in reverse.
He would even go out to farms and talk to farmers about how they could make their processes and their product better suited for industry.
Just the reverse of what food lovers think about today.
Yeah, we think about the slow food movement.
Right, and the locavore movement.
He was trying to correct the locavore movement.
And he was a very garrulous, likeable person and an absolutely brilliant salesman.
When he was trying to get investors, he would send entire dinners of frozen food to their Manhattan apartment.
I mean, he really had a confidence in this product, that if people just tried it, they would love it.
What did you learn from him when you were done with this project, done with spending time with him and writing about him?
I learned a couple of things.
I learned, first of all, how much a person is shaped by the times they lived in.
I think that if Birdseye lived today, he would see a lot of things very differently.
And I also learned that possibilities are limitless if you have the brains and the curiosity and, you know, the chutzpah to go out there and sell them.
Mark Kurlansky.
His new book is ""Birdseye: The Adventures of a Curious Man."" Thanks so much for talking with us, Mark.
We appreciate it.
My pleasure, Rachel.

And you're listening to WEEKEND EDITION from NPR News.
Now, to Iraq, where 49,000 American troops remain.
Of them, 1,600 are assigned to advise and train the Iraqi military and police.
One of the key areas is Iraq's air force.
It was destroyed as a result of the Gulf War in 1991 and the U.S.
invasion in 2003.
Now, the U.S.
Air Force is helping the Iraqis to rebuild it.
It's just one component of what some describe as an emerging long-term strategic relationship between the two countries.
NPR's Mike Shuster looked in on the training in Iraq.
Saddam Hussein spent a lot of money on his air force.
It had Soviet and French jet fighters and all the necessary infrastructure to maintain them combat-ready.
Iraqi fighter pilots went to war in the 1980s against Iran.
That war took its toll and only three years after that, Saddam Hussein was at war again - this time against the United States.
We tried to pursue two F-15s and we couldn't handle that that time, 1991 so.
Lieutenant Colonel Hamid Hussein sits in an air conditioned office at Camp Liberty in Baghdad.
It's in the office of Brigadier General Tony Rock, who is now in charge of the U.S.
project to rebuild the Iraqi air force.
Rock and Hamid look at each other and ponder the possibility that they might have flown missions against each other.
We were both in the Gulf War.
I flew the F-15 while he was flying the Mirage F-1.
Now, the two are working together to build a new Iraqi air force - a daunting challenge, says Colonel Hamid.
After 2003, we started almost from zero.
The Iraqi air force and the Iraqi helicopter capabilities were destroyed in two wars in a 20-year span.
So, the Americans are starting from scratch, training young Iraqi cadets to fly and then training the new pilots to train other novices, and much more, says General Rock.
It's really not just about acquiring airplanes.
Sometimes buying equipment is the easiest thing you do.
It's developing people and it's also making sure that your infrastructure - runways, control towers, hangars, maintenance facilities - are all evolving at the same rate.
(Soundbite of man speaking on radio
Young Iraqi pilots are already in the air, flying every day with their American trainers, learning skills like aerial intelligence and surveillance, in this King Air dual prop plane.
The newest pilot trainees are stationed at Tikrit, north of Baghdad.
The trainees fly a single prop plane called the T-6.
They fly during the day and at night to different parts of Iraq.
And when they return, there is debriefing by the American instructors, sometimes in front of a group of about a dozen trainees.
In one recent session, trainees were presented with a problem, what to do if fire in an engine breaks out.
Captain Josh Martin was critical of how a young Iraqi pilot handled the scenario.
He really hasn't established what is wrong with the aircraft.
He just had lights on the glare shield.
So, once the fire is confirmed and everything like that then run with the rest of the checklist.
Colonel Hamid also takes part in these sessions.
The Iraqi trainees are his men.
Hamid is not satisfied with the way one trainee led another through a complex scenario involving navigating to a runway under duress.
And you let him to eject was not reasonable reason.
He should be able to make the runway.
The Tikrit base is also home to the Iraqi Air Force College, which began operating only last September.
Brigadier General Karim Aziz commands the college.
He too was a fighter pilot in Saddam Hussein's air force but he said he had no trouble making the decision to come back and work with the Americans.
You know the situation outside.
I mean, the situation around Iraq, outside the border, many enemies, many challenge in the front of Iraq.
We have to do something for our country.
The United States is committed to removing the last of its troops by the end of December.
This presents some problems.
Back in Baghdad, Lieutenant General Michael Ferriter, who is in charge of the Iraqi training and advisory mission, acknowledges there are gaps in Iraq's capacity to defend itself.
The U.S.
needs more time, he says, first to get the army capable of defending Iraq's borders.
